metadata.title: PsPM-SPRM: Simultaneous skin conductace, susceptance, and potential measurements, together with ECG, respiration, and eyetracker measurements, from various experimental tasks
metadata.description:
This dataset includes (1) skin conductance (SCR), electrocardiogram (ECG), respiration measurements recorded with Biopac Acknowledge, (2) combined skin conductance, skin potential and skin susceptance response measurements recorded with labview, and (3) eyetracking data for each of 39 healthy unmedicated participants (20 males and 19 females aged 23.9+/-2.6 years), who participated in the following set of experiments:
(1) Resting period of 120 s
(2) Mild pain. 10 uncomfortable electric stimulations are delivered (see below) with an inter trial interval of (uniformly at random) 30, 35 or 40 s.
(3) Auditory oddball task with two different pure sine sounds of 50 ms duration (440 Hz, 660 Hz, randomly assigned per participant to standards and deviants) played at a rate of 1 Hz. Ten sounds are deviants with instruction to press a key when a deviant is detected. The interval between two deviants is drawn uniformly at random from the integers 31-39 seconds. 
(4) Visual detection task. 10 red crosses (RGB 255, 0, 0) are embedded in a 1 Hz stream of white digits (200 ms presentation, 800 ms interval) on a black background. The instruction is to press a key when a red cross is detected. The inter trial interval is randomly determined to be 30, 35 or 40 s.
(5) White noise (1 s duration, 10 ms onset ramp, 85 dB loudness): 10 single sounds, 10 double sounds with 3 s inter stimulus interval, 5 double sounds with 6.5 s inter stimulus interval. Inter trial interval differs between subjects (5 - 6 s).
(6) Pavlovian fear conditioning. CS are two triangles (RGB 255, 176, 0 and 255, 125, 255; randomly assigned per participant to CS+ and CS-) and US is electric stimulation (see below). The instruction is to press the cursor left or right key to indicate the colour of the CS (colour-key mapping randomly assigned per participant). Reinforcement rate for CS+ is 0.5. CS are displayed for 4 s, US starts after 3.5 seconds. Inter-trial interval is 7-11 s. 
(7) Rapid electric shocks to increase tonic skin conductance level. 10 uncomfortable electric stimulations are delivered (see below) with an inter trial interval of 0.5 s.
(8) White noise, as experiment (5). 10 single sounds with an inter trial interval that differs between subjects (6 s, or 30-40 s).

Electric stimulation for experiments (2), (6) and (7) was a 1 s train of 250 electric square pulses, delivered with a constant current stimulator (Digitimer DS7A, Digitimer, Welwyn Garden City, UK) on participants' dominant forearm through a pin-cathode/ring-anode configuration. A pain threshold procedure preceded the experiment, consisting of an staircase until clear pain was reported, followed by ratings of random stimuli.

creators.name: Gerster, Samuel
creators.affiliation: University of Zurich

metadata.title: Integrating Agricultural Literacy Into Social Studies Curriculum: A Design-Based Approach For Sustainable Education In Rural Indonesia
metadata.description:
AGRICULTURAL LITERACY INTEGRATION INTO SOCIAL STUDIES CURRICULUM:

DESIGN-BASED RESEARCH DATA FROM INDRAMAYU REGENCY, INDONESIA

 

RESEARCH OVERVIEW:

This comprehensive dataset contains qualitative and quantitative research data from a design-based research (DBR) study on integrating agricultural literacy into junior secondary Social Studies (IPS) curriculum in Indramayu Regency, West Java, Indonesia.

 

Research Study: "Integrating Agricultural Literacy Into Social Studies Curriculum: A Design-Based Approach For Sustainable Education In Rural Indonesia"

 

Authors: Syahrul Bachtiar & Rusman

Affiliation: Universitas Pendidikan Indonesia (UPI), Department of Curriculum Development

 

DATASET CONTENTS:

 

1. PHASE 1 - NEEDS ANALYSIS DATA

   - Semi-structured interview transcript with 1 MGMP representative (11 main questions; 20 sub-questions)

   - Teacher questionnaire responses: N=306 Social Studies teachers

   - 21-item competency assessment questionnaire (Cronbach's α = 0.934)

   - Document analysis: curriculum syllabi and teaching materials review

   - Key findings: 82% teachers recognize agricultural literacy relevance; 70% lack curricular resources

 

2. PHASE 2 - CURRICULUM DESIGN & VALIDATION

   - Expert curriculum validation data from 3 validators

   - Curriculum design framework and development process

   - Validation scores: Mean 3.81/4.0 (95.2% validity rate)

   - 21 curriculum components evaluated across 3 expert validators

 

3. PHASE 3 - IMPLEMENTATION DATA

   - Semi-structured interview transcripts with 4 Social Studies teachers (G1, G2, G3, G4)

   - Teacher questionnaire responses: 20-item evaluation (N=4)

   - Teacher satisfaction: 298/320 items (93.1%)

   - Student engagement data (N=80 students)

   - Pre-post knowledge assessment results

   - Achievement gains and learning outcome measurements

 

RESEARCH SETTING:

Indramayu Regency, West Java, Indonesia—a major rice-producing region characterized by:

- Extensive agricultural land (predominately rice cultivation)

- Young farmer population decline crisis (63% youth uninterested in agriculture)

- Strong agrarian traditions but limited youth engagement

- Ideal context for studying contextual agricultural literacy integration

 

RESEARCH METHODOLOGY:

Design-Based Research approach across three phases:

- Phase 1: Needs analysis through interviews and questionnaires

- Phase 2: Curriculum design and expert validation

- Phase 3: Implementation with classroom trials and student learning assessment

 

DATA CHARACTERISTICS:

- Language: English (questionnaire items and interview transcripts translated from Indonesian)

- Participants: 306 teachers (Phase 1); 4 teachers (Phase 3); 80 students (Phase 3)

- Data types: Interview transcripts, questionnaire responses, assessment data, validation rubrics

- Instruments: Semi-structured interview protocols, 21-item questionnaire, student engagement scales, pre-post knowledge tests

- Time frame: 2024-2025

 

KEY FINDINGS SUMMARY:

- Teacher Recognition: 82% recognize agricultural literacy as highly relevant to Social Studies

- Resource Gap: 70% teachers report lacking curricular resources for implementation

- Student Engagement: 85% reported lessons as highly relevant (Phase 3)

- Knowledge Gains: 18.3% mean improvement pre-post (Cohen's d = 1.21, large effect)

- Attitudinal Change: 100% of students reported increased respect for farmers

- Career Interest: 42% showed increased interest in agricultural careers

- Teacher Satisfaction: 93.1% rated curriculum implementation very positively

- Curriculum Validation: 95.2% validity rate from expert validators

 

RESEARCH ETHICS:

- Ethical Approval: Universitas Pendidikan Indonesia Research Ethics Committee (Approval No. B-5093/UN40.A1.1/TD.07/2025)

- Informed Consent: All participants provided informed consent prior to data collection

- Confidentiality: Participant data anonymized; identifying information removed

- Voluntary Participation: All participants informed of voluntary nature and right to withdraw

 

DATASET FILES INCLUDED:

1. Interview_Transcript_Teachers.docx - Teacher interview transcripts (Phase 1 & 3)

2. Needs-Analysis.xlsx - Complete questionnaire data from 306 teachers with statistical summaries

3. Implementation-Results.xlsx - Teacher (N=4) and student (N=80) evaluation data with pre-post assessment results

4. Expert-curriculum-validation.xlsx - Expert validator ratings and curriculum validation data

 

USE CASES:

This dataset is valuable for:

- Understanding teacher and student perspectives on agricultural literacy integration

- Examining contextual curriculum design in rural agricultural regions

- Studying design-based research implementation in Indonesian educational contexts

- Supporting evidence-based arguments for agricultural education in Social Studies

- Informing international curriculum development efforts in sustainable education

- Contributing to research on youth engagement with agriculture and food systems

 

STATISTICAL INFORMATION:

- Teacher questionnaire: Cronbach's α = 0.934 (excellent internal consistency)

- Knowledge assessment: t(79) = 17.79, p < 0.001 (highly significant improvement)

- Expert validation: Mean 3.81/4.0; SD = 0.43; 95.2% validity

- Student engagement ratings: Mean 3.83/4.0 on 18-item scale

- Teacher implementation satisfaction: 93.1% (298/320 items scored favorably)

 

CITATION FORMAT (APA 7th Edition):

Bachtiar, S., & Rusman. (2025). Interview transcripts and research data: Agricultural literacy integration into social studies curriculum—Indramayu Regency, Indonesia [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.17500112

 

ATTRIBUTION:

Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC-BY 4.0)

 

RELATED PUBLICATIONS:

Bachtiar, S., & Rusman. (2025). Integrating agricultural literacy into social studies curriculum: A design-based research approach for sustainable education in rural Indonesia. [Journal article submitted/pending]

 

CONTACT:

For inquiries regarding this dataset, please contact: syahrulbachtiar@upi.edu

metadata.title: L'irrévocabilité des arrêts de la cour constitutionnelle à l'épreuve de l'indérogeabilité du droit de recours en droit positif congolais : Analyses et Perspectives
metadata.description: The irrevocability of judgments rendered by the Constitutional Court constitutes one of the cardinal principles of the Congolese legal order. It aims to guarantee the stability of judicial decisions and legal certainty by conferring upon these judgments an absolute and final authority. However, this irrevocability, elevated to the rank of an intangible principle, encounters the fundamental requirement of the right to appeal, recognized by the Constitution of February 18, 2006, as amended and supplemented by Law No. 11/002 of January 20, 2011, as well as by international human rights instruments as a non-derogable right. This paradox raises a central question: how can the need for stability of constitutional rulings be reconciled with the imperative of guaranteeing every litigant an effective remedy against a decision tainted by error or manifest injustice? Through an in-depth doctrinal and jurisprudential analysis, this article examines the compatibility between the irrevocability of Constitutional Court judgments and the principle of non-derogability of the right to appeal, within the framework of Congolese positive law. It also proposes possible reform pathways aimed at ensuring a better balance between the authority of res judicata in constitutional matters and the effective protection of fundamental rights.

journal.title: Revue Internationale de la Recherche Scientifique (Revue-IRS) - ISSN : 2958-8413

data.title: L'irrévocabilité des arrêts de la cour constitutionnelle à l'épreuve de l'indérogeabilité du droit de recours en droit positif congolais : Analyses et Perspectives

metadata.title: Simultaneous Determination of Metronidazole and Miconazole Nitrate in Pharmaceutical Formulations by RP-HPLC with Greener Solvent
metadata.description: The aim of this study was to develop a simple, sensitive, accurate, efficient and reproducible Reverse-Phase High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (RP-HPLC) method that maintains stability for the simultaneous determination of Miconazole nitrate and metronidazole in vaginal gel formulations. Using a diode array detector at 210 nm, chromatography was conducted on a Zorbax SB-8 column (150 × 4.6 mm, 3.5 μm) under linear elution with a combination of solvent A (water) and solvent B (isopropyl alcohol) as the mobile phase, including a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. The linearity of metronidazole and Miconazole nitrate exhibited correlation coefficients of 0.9997 and 0.9995, respectively. The limits of detection and quantification were 0.05 μg/mL and 0.42 μg/mL for metronidazole and 0.16 μg/mL and 1.24 μg/mL for Miconazole nitrate. The technique yielded good results, with recovery rates between 98.0% and 102.0% and repeatability of ≤ 2.0%. This method is suitable for routine quality control testing of dosage forms containing these compounds due to its straightforwardness, accuracy and precision. The method's run time is reduced, leading to a lower solvent requirement. The analytical method was developed and validated to comply with ICH guidelines.

creators.name: Mrunalini, Kulkarni
creators.affiliation: Department of Chemistry, Maharshi Dayanand College of Arts, Science and Commerce, Parel, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

creators.name: Pranay, More
creators.affiliation: Department of Chemistry, Maharshi Dayanand College of Arts, Science and Commerce, Parel, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

metadata.title: MAS-MCP City - Reproducible LLM-agent coordination with MCP over NGSI-LD/SensorThings
metadata.description:
🏙️ MAS-MCP City v1.0.0

Reproducible LLM-agent coordination with MCP over NGSI-LD / SensorThings

🇬🇧 Release Notes (English)

Highlights

  • Updated architecture: all MCP servers (NGSI-LD, STA, Actuation) now use the official Anthropic Model Context Protocol SDK v1.20.2.
  • Capability-gated tool-use: OPA sidecar authorization, per-tool budgets, and explicit scope metadata (ngsi, sta, bms, mqtt).
  • Observability: full OpenTelemetry integration (OTLP HTTP/gRPC + Prometheus metrics).
  • Agents: new mcp-client library and iaq-orchestrator workflow for SmartCampus IAQ / occupancy analytics.
  • Helm Charts: unified platform, observability, and agents charts with hardened Kubernetes policies.
  • Reproducibility: fixtures, CI pipelines, and shareable traces validated against Figures 5–8 of the paper.

Compatibility

  • Backwards-compatible with all v0.9 charts and test fixtures.
  • Requires Node ≥ 20 and Kubernetes ≥ 1.25.

Deployment Summary

helm upgrade --install masmcp-obs charts/observability -n masmcp
helm upgrade --install masmcp charts/platform -n masmcp -f charts/platform/values-dev.yaml
helm upgrade --install masmcp-agents charts/agents -n masmcp

Citation

F. Maciá-Pérez, I. Lorenzo-Fonseca, À. Maciá-Fiteni, MAS-MCP City: Reproducible LLM-agent coordination with MCP over NGSI-LD/SensorThings for traceable SmartCampus IAQ and occupancy analytics, Future Generation Computer Systems, 2025. DOI → 10.5281/zenodo.17500006

🇪🇸 Notas de lanzamiento (Spanish)

Aspectos destacados

  • Arquitectura actualizada: todos los servidores MCP (NGSI-LD, STA y Actuación) usan el SDK oficial Anthropic MCP v1.20.2.
  • Ejecución segura por capacidades: autorización mediante OPA sidecar, presupuestos por herramienta y metadatos de scope (ngsi, sta, bms, mqtt).
  • Observabilidad completa: integración OpenTelemetry (OTLP HTTP/gRPC y métricas Prometheus).
  • Agentes: nuevas bibliotecas mcp-client y iaq-orchestrator para análisis de IAQ y ocupación en campus.
  • Charts Helm: platform, observability y agents unificados con políticas de seguridad Kubernetes reforzadas.
  • Reproducibilidad: fixtures, CI y trazas compartibles verificadas con las Figuras 5–8 del artículo.

Compatibilidad

  • Totalmente compatible con las versiones v0.9 de charts y fixtures.
  • Requiere Node ≥ 20 y Kubernetes ≥ 1.25.

Despliegue rápido

helm upgrade --install masmcp-obs charts/observability -n masmcp
helm upgrade --install masmcp charts/platform -n masmcp -f charts/platform/values-dev.yaml
helm upgrade --install masmcp-agents charts/agents -n masmcp

Cita

F. Maciá-Pérez, I. Lorenzo-Fonseca, À. Maciá-Fiteni, MAS-MCP City: Reproducible LLM-agent coordination with MCP over NGSI-LD/SensorThings for traceable SmartCampus IAQ and occupancy analytics, Future Generation Computer Systems, 2025. DOI → 10.5281/zenodo.17500006

License: CC BY-NC 4.0 | Tag: v1.0.0 | Date: 2025-10-31

metadata.title: Congenital Megalocornea, Microspherophakia, and Lens Subluxation Leading to Secondary Glaucoma in an Infant: A Case of Suspected LTBP2 Mutation
metadata.description: We report the case of a 6-month-old infant with congenital megalocornea, microspherophakia, and bilateral lens subluxation, leading to secondary glaucoma. Genetic context included consanguinity, suggesting an LTBP2-related condition. The patient underwent bilateral lensectomy with anterior vitrectomy, combined with trabeculectomy and peripheral iridectomy in the right eye. Postoperative intraocular pressure normalized in both eyes. This rare entity should be distinguished from primary congenital glaucoma, as the surgical approach differs. Regular intraocular pressure monitoring is essential in children with megalocornea and lens anomalies to ensure early detection and treatment of secondary glaucoma.

metadata.title: THE ROLE OF EFFECTIVE TIME AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN BUSINESS PERFORMANCE: COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF CORPORATE PRACTICES IN DEVELOPED ECONOMIES
metadata.description: This thesis investigates the impact of effective time and resource management on corporate performance and competitiveness. The study emphasizes the integration of time management, digitalization, and human capital development as core components of organizational sustainability. Drawing insights from developed economies such as the United States, Germany, and Japan, the research demonstrates that time management is not simply an administrative routine but a strategic determinant of innovation, adaptability, and productivity. Empirical evidence indicates that firms applying structured time management systems achieve up to 30% higher operational efficiency, 25% faster decision-making, and 20% better employee satisfaction levels. These findings align with both corporate and educational models of time efficiency, including the academic framework studied by Azimov (2024) at Baku Higher Oil School [6].

data.title: THE ROLE OF EFFECTIVE TIME AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN BUSINESS PERFORMANCE: COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF CORPORATE PRACTICES IN DEVELOPED ECONOMIES
